learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate a thorough knowledge of communication and counselling as it applies to dietetic practice, including a range of theoretical frameworks and practical application of these

Demonstrate effective and appropriate skills in communicating information, advice, education and professional opinion to individuals and groups, demonstrating respect for culture within the over-arching principles of person-centred care
Identify barriers to change for the client, drawing upon relevant counselling methods and strategies to address these in collaboration with  the client
Recognise the role of language and appropriate verbal and non-verbal cues; strengths-based communication and applied knowledge of culturally safe health practice.

assessments.task_description:
This assessment consists of a series of short quizzes delivered across the semester. The quizzes are designed to support regular engagement with course content and to consolidate foundational concepts related to interviewing, counselling, professional communication, and culturally safe practice in dietetics.

Quiz questions focus on the application of counselling and communication principles to practice-based scenarios rather than detailed clinical content. As the semester progresses, quizzes may include short answer questions to support students’ ability to articulate counselling reasoning, reflect on language use, and apply theoretical frameworks to practical situations.

Each quiz is low-stakes and contributes a small proportion of the overall mark. Together, the quizzes provide ongoing opportunities for retrieval practice, formative feedback, and incremental skill development in preparation for later practice-based assessments.

Use of Artificial Intelligence

The weekly quizzes in DIET7103 are designed to support regular engagement with course content and the development of foundational knowledge and applied understanding of interviewing, counselling, and professional communication.

Online quizzes are completed not in person and are intended to support learning and consolidation of course content. Students may use AI tools in a limited and transparent manner to support understanding of concepts or revision (for example, clarifying terminology or checking understanding of lecture material).

AI tools must not be used to generate answers, select responses on the student’s behalf, or replace the student’s own reasoning. Students remain responsible for ensuring that quiz responses reflect their own understanding.

Use of AI or MT tools in ways that substitute for genuine engagement or misrepresent authorship may constitute student misconduct under the UQ Student Code of Conduct.

Further guidance regarding permitted AI use is available via Blackboard.
assessments.submission_guidelines: To be completed as an online quiz via the course Blackboard site
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Length: 500 words (±10%)

Condition: Completion of mandated cultural safety modules (DIET7103)

Task Description

Students are required to submit a critical reflection examining the role of cultural safety in dietetic counselling and professional communication. This task focuses on the application of cultural safety principles to counselling practice, rather than on general cultural awareness or description of course content.

A critical reflection requires students to go beyond describing what was learned to critically examine how cultural safety influences their communication choices, assumptions, and professional responsibilities as developing dietitians. Students are expected to demonstrate insight, self-awareness, and integration of theory with practice.

Reflections should draw on learning from:

  • the mandated cultural safety modules
  • counselling and communication content from DIET7103
  • relevant class activities or case discussions
  • early professional practice experiences (for example, UQ clinics or simulated practice, where applicable)

Students are encouraged to consider how cultural safety shapes:

  • language and communication choices
  • power and positionality in counselling interactions
  • strengths-based and person-centred practice
  • engagement with diverse clients and communities

Guidance for Critical Reflection

A strong reflection will:

  • demonstrate thoughtful self-reflection rather than description
  • identify assumptions or challenges encountered or anticipated
  • link cultural safety principles to counselling practice
  • provide specific examples to support reflection
  • consider how learning will influence future professional practice

Students will receive guidance and exemplars on critical reflection techniques during the course.

Use of Artificial Intelligence

This assessment task evaluates students’ ability to engage in critical self-reflection on cultural safety, professional identity, and counselling practice.

The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools to generate, rewrite, paraphrase, or substantially draft reflective content is not permitted for this assessment. Students are expected to demonstrate their own insight, professional voice, and reflective thinking.

Students may use AI tools for general study support only, such as clarifying terminology, checking understanding of concepts discussed in class, or assisting with study planning. Any use of AI tools must not replace the student’s own thinking or reflective process.

Use of AI or MT in ways that obscure authorship or substitute for genuine reflection may constitute student misconduct under the UQ Student Code of Conduct.

Further guidance regarding permitted and prohibited AI use is available via Blackboard.
assessments.submission_guidelines: This assessment will be submitted through ePortfolio.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Assessment Description

Students will submit a recorded counselling interaction demonstrating an interview with a client up to and including the explanation of a diet–disease relationship. The interaction does not require completion of a full nutrition assessment, diagnosis, or intervention planning.

Accompanying the recording, students will complete a guided reflective analysis responding to structured metacognitive prompts. The reflection focuses on counselling style, communication choices, responsiveness to the client, and identification of areas for future professional development.

Skills Assessed

This assessment evaluates students’ ability to demonstrate and reflect on:

  • counselling and interviewing process
  • explanation of diet–disease relationships using client-centred language
  • self-reflection and metacognitive awareness
  • professional and respectful communication

Video Task Parameters

  • The recorded interaction will typically be 10-15 minutes in length.
  • Students may work with a peer or simulated client.
  • The interaction should progress from initial engagement to an explanation of a diet–disease relationship in client-centred language.

Students are not expected to complete a full nutrition assessment or provide an intervention plan.

Reflection Parameters

  • Reflections will respond to structured prompts provided in the course materials.
  • Marking will prioritise depth of insight, self-awareness, and reflection on counselling process, rather than technical performance or clinical completeness.

Use of Artificial Intelligence

AI tools may be used in a limited and transparent manner to support preparation, reflection, or self-analysis for this assessment.

AI tools must not be used to generate counselling interactions, simulate client responses, or replace student performance in the recorded interaction.

For further details regarding permitted and prohibited AI use, students should consult information provided via Blackboard.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The written component of this assignment is to be submitted through ePortfolio. The video component can be uploaded to your ePortfolio.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Objective Structured Clinical Examination (OSCE) – Interviewing and Counselling Process
assessments.task_description:
Assessment Description

This assessment requires students to participate in an Objective Structured Clinical Examination (OSCE) involving a structured, simulated consultation with a trained actor. The OSCE focuses on how students conduct the interaction, including their questioning approach, active listening, responsiveness to client cues, and professional communication.

The OSCE intentionally does not assess completion of a full nutrition assessment, diagnosis, documentation, or intervention planning. The emphasis is on interviewing and counselling process, rather than the completeness or accuracy of nutrition information collected.

Purpose

This assessment evaluates students’ foundational counselling and interviewing skills in a time-limited, simulated practice environment. It supports the development of interactional competence, relational safety, and professional confidence, and prepares students for progression into subjects focused on medical nutrition therapy and clinical practice, where full assessment and intervention skills are developed.

Skills Assessed

This assessment evaluates students’ ability to demonstrate:

  • effective questioning strategies and sequencing
  • active listening and responsiveness to client cues
  • rapport building and maintenance of relational safety
  • professional communication and consultation structure

Nature of the OSCE

  • The OSCE will consist of a single interviewing and counselling-focused station.
  • Scenarios will reflect early or exploratory consultations, rather than complex or advanced clinical presentations.
  • Students will be assessed on interactional competence and counselling process, not clinical completeness or technical accuracy.

Assessment Security

This assessment is secure and completed in person under supervised conditions.

Use of Artificial Intelligence

The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools is not permitted during the OSCE.

For further details regarding assessment conditions and AI use, students should consult information provided via Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.
